content:
Hi all,

I had an idea for how we can spread around the knowledge of rustdoc's code. We could have a "rustdoc reading meeting" where team members (and maybe regular contributors too) meet to read different parts of the code. Then, people who are "expert" in those areas can help people who are less knowledgeable understand the code.

This is kind of what I was hoping for from the rustc reading club, but that has somewhat different goals. This meeting would be explicitly focused on people who are already knowledgeable about rustdoc but are missing knowledge about certain parts. That way we can review more PRs and don't have to just rely on one or two people who know that code well.

Some potential area -> expert mappings (feel free to comment with adjustments):

  • intra-doc links: Manish Goregaokar and Noah Lev
  • clean: GuillaumeGomez and Noah Lev
  • JS, CSS, and UI in general: GuillaumeGomez and jsha
  • rendering: GuillaumeGomez, jsha, and (at least partially) Noah Lev
  • source code highlighting: GuillaumeGomez
These are based mostly on what areas I know, so I'm sure I'm missing things
This is a very good idea and I strongly support it!
@Noah Lev: I would maybe add the source code highlight which is a bit "on its own" too.

I created a HackMD for the "rustdoc expert map" (at some point we might want to move it somewhere more permanent, but this is a start): https://hackmd.io/@camelid/SJkwoPvhK

Feel free to add to it
@Michael Howell You might be interested by this too I think ;)
Joshua suggests that we should consider doing an edition of the meeting with Will Crichton on how scrape-examples works. @Will Crichton would you be interested in that?
Yes I would be happy to do that. I can also provide some perspective as a rustdoc newcomer, e.g. all the things I didn't understand when I first filed my PR / RFC.
Great, hopefully we'll be able to start these meetings sometime soon :)
ooh yeah I'm particularly interested in your perspective as a rustdoc newcomer! I'd like to improve our onboarding documentation.
If anyone is interested in how the JSON rendering works I'd be willing to talk about that
I could give a tour of the JS/CSS frontend stuff; or probably most useful, how to use Dev Tools to debug UI / JS issues.

Ok, I've created a HackMD with a list of topics and people: https://hackmd.io/@camelid/SkFlY32nY

Feel free to add to the list
I could probably give a tour of clean and intra-doc links (maybe @Manish Goregaokar could help with the latter as well)
